comments.text:
+G00Dlord  Sure. He overreacts. He shouldn't have burned the Christmas 
tree. But let's look at it from his point of view. He asks for only one 
thing. One. He simply wants a WiiU (I believe that's what he said. After 
all, that's what he got). He buys a $100+ grill for his dad (When he points 
this out to his dad, he says "I already have a grill!" That's not 
ungrateful?)
And what does he get?
Antlers.
Cheap ass, low-quality antlers worth $50.
What did his brother get?
$500 worth of gifts.
You'd be pretty upset too if your dad was so ungrateful and got you next to 
nothing.
Luckily for Jesse, his mom pulled through. Not his dad. His mom.
What else does Jesse do?
Let's see, he did smash a TV screen... But, wait... No, the dad deserved 
that... I mean, once you've had everything you owned destroyed then you 
were told to pay for your friend's GBA which your dad broke simply because 
you were looking at the screen (There's no evidence he was doing more than 
looking at the screen), you'll be pissed. Sure, he shouldn't have gone to 
the dad's level, but the dad still deserved it
The chainsaw prank? He was only doing it to get back at his dad for doing 
the exact same thing. And what does the dad do? He becomes a hypocrite and 
says normal people don't do that stuff (When he himself did it before 
(Notice that neither the dad nor the brother denied it happened)) and began 
to sledgehammer and chainsaw Jesse's XBOX One.
Then other time the dad heard Jesse got some money from his mom (Though, 
the dad forced Jesse to say that. He was giving him no other options. 
"Birthday and Christmas money don't count". Yeah right.) and used it to fix 
the XBOX that his dad destroyed. The dad, after hearing that, threw the 
XBOX into the car Jesse was going to use to get to a job interview and then 
went on to destroy the car, after Jesse told his dad that was his car to 
get around in so he couldn't get to the interview (Wait. Didn't the dad 
WANT Jesse to get a new job before? You can't win with this guy!)
Then, to avoid his dad's crazy antics, instead of playing in the house, he 
decided to secretly play in the garage. Of course, the dad found out and 
threw the XBOX into the pool... Because... reasons...
Then the dad shredded Jesse's games with a lawn mower, telling Jesse to get 
a job even after Jesse said he already had a job (Yes, livestreaming is a 
job and I'm willing to back this point up if necessary.)
I won't defend the Thanksgiving thing. Both sides were totally in the wrong 
there (Though, Jesse did apologize and he admitted he was wrong.)
And finally, the livestream raid. After Jesse was making some side comments 
about his dad (Which, sure, he shouldn't have been doing and he again 
admitted he was wrong in the update video), his dad rushed in and destroyed 
the monitor.


Hm. In that giant wall of text, I hear more of the dad acting out than 
Jesse. (The screaming and yelling don't count, as that's part of the 
duration and the aftermath of the destruction, so it's justifiable. You'd 
be upset too.)
So, even if Jesse IS the cause, the dad is still far more in the wrong than 
Jesse.
comments.author: TallMist

obtained the belongings his father destroyed. If the items were gifted to

money then he could sue over that. Of course they would not be at retail 
price. There value would be lowered depending on age, how long he had them, 
and how much he actually spent on it. No one sells gameboys anymore besides 
maybe pawn shops and ebay. They don't sell games for the console outside 
those places either.

comments.text:
+Brittney Pratt Autism(and everything under the autism spectrum) is a 
social development disorder, and as such isn't an excuse for bad grammar. 
While autism can in certain situations cause abnormal development in other 
areas of the brain(and is usually just ignored and treated as an 
side-effect, and not an secondary diagnosis), that'd have t be actually 
established, all you've stated is that you have a social development 
disorder, and as such it's not an excuse for poor grammar.

Besides, I'm an asperger(so within the autistic spectrum) myself, and I do 
have an extreme problem learning languages(I didn't learn to use proper 
punctuation until age of 18, and I am litteraly incapable of learning 
gramatical rules, I just memorize situations or pick what sounds most 
correctly based on reading it out-loud, for instance an car doesn't sound 
right, but a car sounds right, so it must be a car),

yet I still have managed to learn the difference between your and 
you're(easy way to remember the difference; if the sentence is "you are" 
then it's you're,  if it isn't you are, then it's your. it can't get 
simpler then that), so again: not really a valid excuse.
comments.author: Skn

top_comment.text:
People say all this psycho stuff is faked. Tell me this: how? This shit 
just shows how dramatic things can be. That $1000 or so TV, the laptop, the 
XBOX, the camera, and all those games, all that money, shit on and flushed. 
And that family is probably doomed, right when the TV was hit. If it was 
all faked, these guys need to go to fucking Hollywood, because if that 
really is the case, that would be the best acting I've seen in a while. I 
have no fucking idea why this was shown to millions of people in the first 
place, but, while there is entertainment in this, we all need to sympathize 
for these guys. The guy's life is probably destroyed since his games got 
the mower treatment, and now he is, as far as I know, permanently kicked 
out of the house. The dad must feel bad, looking back since Christmas, 
2012, at what has happened and what millions of people saw. Yes, he 
disobeyed his father, and was punished. In an extreme way. Ever since, he 
must not have been the same. He did get revenge, but now this happens. 
These guys seem to be in real trouble now. We need to sympathize, not keep 
saying, "this is all fake, we r smurt! Heheheheheheheheheheeeeeeeeeeeeee". 
No. And anyone who thinks my way of thinking is wrong, and wishes to 
discredit me, come at me. I accept. I will tear your petty arguments apart. 
Saying this is all fake is likely slowly, but surely, tearing these guys 
farther and farther apart. Show support, don't be a dick. That is all.﻿

comments.text:
I'm pretty sure this is fake but I will humour you and act as if it is real.

As someone who grew up with an abusive father (more abusive than this one, 
but it was a similar principal toward the end) I will tell you straight up 
that this approach does not work. It actually drives you to be the 
opposite. I wasted several years of my early adult life avoiding getting a 
job at all costs, even when I was homeless. It creates a me vs them 
mentality and the idea of getting a job meant my father had won. It may 
seem silly to you but when you are brought up this way you don't think 
straight. Your hatred for your abuser overrides all logical thought. The 
only thing you ever want is to not be like your farther, and more often 
than not in such cases the father is trying to mould his son in his own 
image. These sort of fathers are often narcissistic and the problem more 
often than not lies deeper than the actual want for the son to get a job. 
My father was never happy with me. I could do everything he said and there 
would just be another issue after that. Not every father is automatically 
right and such an attitude is dangerous.

This approach will leave your kids severely depressed, full of social 
anxiety and a whole ton of trust issues. Sure they might get a job, but 
they likely wont live a happy life because you will have fucked them up 
mentally. In the end there are more important things in life than having a 
job. If you put having a job over the mental stability and happiness of 
your child then you need to re-evaluate your priorities in life. You work 
so you can live a life, you do not live a life just so you can work. This 
method of parenting will leave you with an empty shell of a son/daughter, a 
drone that will eventually have a job but no other redeeming qualities. No 
need for most of the money they make because nothing makes them happy any 
more.

If you want your kid to get a job use positive incentive. "If you get a job 
you can buy this and that" as they get older buy them less things to drive 
that incentive. This sets up a job as a positive rather than a negative. 
The chores for an allowance method sets up the idea of a job well. If they 
want something tell them that they can save up their allowance to buy it. 
Then "if you get a real job you can earn a lot more money than that and get 
things much quicker".

Building on the illogic of negative reinforcement is only going to hurt 
your cause. How do you expect your child to have the confidence to get a 
job, when you spend all your time telling him he is a lazy and good for 
nothing in the most impressionable time of their life? If the person who 
pretty much has to love you has no confidence in you, then you likely 
aren't going to have confidence in yourself. With me it got to the point 
where I was close to having an anxiety attack just from handing a C.V in. 
In interviews I was a nervous wreck and couldn't sell myself as I had been 
told for years that I had no redeeming qualities.

I'm all for discipline, but there is a difference between discipline and 
abuse. This is abuse. Discipline is taking his game/console away, abuse is 
destroying them in a very violent manner to the point were the kid feels 
threatened for his safety. In the end if the kid is 20+ and is immature 
then the father's method of parenting obviously hasn't worked has it.

Sorry for the essay but wanted to give you the point of view of someone who 
actually went through this.
